title: Paget Disease of the Nipple
diagnosis_topic: Breast cancer presenting as nipple eczema
setup_script: A 55-year-old woman complains of persistent itchy, scaly rash on the right nipple for 6 months unresponsive to topical steroids. On exam, the nipple is eczematous with slight discharge. Palpation reveals no mass.

dynamic_flow.trigger: Take history of nipple changes, discharge, and any underlying breast lump or systemic symptoms.
Perform clinical exam; assess both breasts and axilla; note unilateral eczematous changes unresponsive to treatment.
Order diagnostic mammogram and ultrasound to evaluate for underlying DCIS or invasive carcinoma.
Perform punch biopsy of nipple lesion to confirm Paget disease and evaluate for underlying carcinoma.
Discuss pathology results; explain that Paget disease is often associated with underlying DCIS or invasive cancer.

Plan surgical management based on imaging: if no palpable mass and limited DCIS, consider central lumpectomy (nipple-areolar complex removal) with radiation; if multifocal disease, perform mastectomy.
Discuss sentinel lymph node biopsy at time of surgery due to risk of invasive component.
Obtain informed consent; explain aesthetic outcomes and reconstruction options if mastectomy performed.
Perform surgery as planned; orient specimen; send sentinel nodes for pathological evaluation.
Postoperative care: manage wounds, discuss adjuvant radiation or endocrine therapy based on pathology.
Educate patient on prognosis, risk of recurrence, and need for surveillance on contralateral breast.
Provide support resources and address psychological impact of nipple loss or mastectomy.

critical_decision_points: Recognizing Paget disease and performing biopsy for diagnosis.
Appropriate imaging to detect underlying carcinoma.
Tailoring surgical approach based on presence and extent of underlying disease.
Performing sentinel lymph node biopsy for invasive component.
Providing reconstruction options and psychosocial support.
